text: Specific disruption of <extra_id_0> NFAT5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> binding impairs LTR - driven transcription in THP-1 cells in response to MTb stimulation

Although the transcription factor <extra_id_0> NFAT5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> binds to a core NF-kappaB binding motif in the HIV-1 LTR enhancer region of subtype B , when two thymines ( TT ) are changed to cytosines ( CC ) in the proximal NF-kappaB binding motif ( named N5-Mut ) ( bottom of Figure 1B ) , the binding of <extra_id_0> NFAT5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> can be disrupted while leaving binding of NF-kappaB unperturbed [ 31 ] .

We examined the requirement of <extra_id_0> NFAT5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> for MTb - induced LTR activity by transfecting a wild-type and NFAT5 mutant LTR reporter construct into THP-1 cells , followed by stimulation with an MTb lysate .
As shown in Figure 1B , in the absence of MTb lysate stimulation the activity of the NFAT5 binding site - mutant LTR was significantly reduced ( p < 0.05 ) in comparison to the wild-type LTR .
When the NFAT5 binding site - mutant LTR was examined in THP-1 cells stimulated with the MTb lysate , its activity was reduced to an even more significant extent ( p < 0.01 ) .

To determine whether MTb lysate stimulation directly enhances <extra_id_0> NFAT5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression in THP-1 cells , we stimulated cells for 8 or 24 hours or left them unstimulated and examined <extra_id_0> NFAT5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein levels by western blot .

As shown in Figure 1C , we found that <extra_id_0> NFAT5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein levels steadily increased in response to MTb lysate stimulation , revealing that TLR engagement by MTb results in enhanced levels of <extra_id_0> NFAT5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , consistent with its playing a role in MTb - induced activation of the HIV-1 LTR .
